Description: Pottery askos in form of bull; wheel-made body with a finely detailed, mould-made head; the spout and handle are hand-made and applied; four short stumpy legs; strap handle from the behind the animal's head to the middle of the back; tubular spout inserted into the front of the body; hole at rear of the body, for filling the vessel or else to facilitate firing; incised branch-motif on sides of body; buff-pink clay; repaired from fragments, surface abraded in places.
Curator's comments: This is probably the vessel illustrated in Alessandro Palma di Cesnola's Salaminia (1882, pl. XX, no. 16). See Lund 2015, 149-151 for a discussion of the type (with previous references and further examples cat. nos 1678-1703). They are closely related to the wheelmade pig/boar-shaped rattles of Hellenistic date. Bibliography: Cesnola, A. 1882, Salaminia (London).
Bibliographic references: Lund 2015 / A study of the circulation of ceramics in Cyprus from the 3rd century BC to the 3rd century AD (Cat. no. 1678; p. 149-150, fig. 226)
Acquisition name: Transferred from: Victoria and Albert Museum
Previous owner: Previous owner/ex-collection: Alessandro Palma di Cesnola
Acquisition notes: Originally bought by Rollin & Feuerdent at the Lawrence-Cesnola sale at Sotheby's 25-27 April 1892, Lot 513 (which included 1981,8-10.2 and 4) who sold it to the South Kensington Museum. The vessel is specifically mentioned in the lot description, 'Phoenician oenochoe, very fine colour; Water Vessel, or askos; Tetine, in form of a bull; and others.'
